description.plain:
“She” was first uploaded on dodie’s YouTube channel in September 2014 and became her first song to hit 1 million views on YouTube. She often plays the song while on tour and announced in September 2018 it would feature on her EP, Human.

She has said that, “This is such an old song! I was ready to leave it well be until I played it live at a specific show and realised I wanted to give it a new life”
https://youtu.be/1_-pKR-s0qc?t=238

body.plain:
“She” was first uploaded on dodie’s YouTube channel in September 2014 and became her first song to hit 1 million views on YouTube. She often plays the song while on tour and announced in September 2018 it would feature on her EP, Human.

She has said that, “This is such an old song! I was ready to leave it well be until I played it live at a specific show and realised I wanted to give it a new life”
https://youtu.be/1_-pKR-s0qc?t=238

songs.full_title: Dodie - She (Türkçe Çeviri) by Genius Türkçe Çeviri
songs.title: Dodie - She (Türkçe Çeviri)

annotations:
And oh, it aches
 But it feels oddly good to hurt
And I’ll be okay admiring from afar
I think what she’s saying here is that no matter how straight there girl is doesn’t matter. Liking her was good enough, because she could still “admire from afar.”
And she means everything to me, oh

While being in young love, you tend to overlook relationships that may or may not be very healthy for the human embodiment. While she may feel so very strongly towards this girl, late in the song Dodie says, “But to her, I taste of nothing at all” implying it’s a one-sided crush that most of us at one point in our lives all end up having

The definition of a one-sided crush is this: Your crush simply isn’t aware or interested in your well-being or making you happy. They usually happen quite a lot to people.

Overall, she hides this crush from the world as this younger adolescent because she doesn’t even know if this feeling is allowed.

Am I allowed
 To look at her like that?
 Could it be wrong
 When she’s just so nice to look at?

These lyrics address the stigma that Dodie and many others were raised with – the heteronormative idea that only men and women are ‘allowed’ to be attracted to each other.
But when Dodie is attracted to another girl, she feels that it can’t be wrong because of how natural it feels to her and how much she enjoys it.

’Cause even when she’s next to me
 We could not be more far apart

Even though the pair are such close friends, Dodie will always want more, physically and emotionally, and it can never happen because the girl in question is straight and because of this, she will never want or understand the kind of closeness that Dodie craves.
But to her, I taste of nothing at all

Keyword is: nothing. The narrator is not remotely within her line of interest because she is straight. If the narrator “tasted” like something she doesn’t like, or something bad, it would imply that it was a matter of preference, that the narrator is just not her type, but the narrator tastes of nothing to her.

And she smells like lemongrass and sleep
 She tastes like apple juice and peach

In a live performance of the song dodie said of this lyric:


To be honest, that was such a seventeen year old lyric and like, I cringe every time I sing it. […] I just wanted to like, kinda, I didn’t know how to convey the feeling of, like, comfort and, like, excitement and sweetness that I felt liking a girl.

But then, when I sing the line “but to her I taste of nothing at all” I’m like okay, that kind of, like, makes that terrible metaphor a bit better.
Oh, you would find her in a Polaroid picture

Polaroid is a camera brand which started with instant photography. The term “Polaroid” however, is now often used to refer to instant photography in general which can be seen as a more artistic, nostalgic form of photography.

I’d never tell
 No, I’d never say a word

In her video #askbidodie, Dodie says that the song was based on an experience she had when she very young. She did not recognize her romantic feelings until many years later, because the world she grew up in was very unwelcoming. Although she did not recognize these as romantic feeling, she did not tell anyone because she had so often been denied the opportunity and told that it was “just a phase”.

description.plain:
“Would You Be So Kind?” is the sixth and final track on Dodie’s second EP, titled You.

Dodie has previously performed this song live on her 2017 Intertwined Tour, and she uploaded a version of the song on her YouTube channel “doddleoddle” on September 18th, 2016 and another version with her band on the tour bus for the 2017 tour.

songs.title: Dodie - Would You Be So Kind? (Türkçe Çeviri)
songs.title_with_featured: Dodie - Would You Be So Kind? (Türkçe Çeviri)

translation_songs.title: Dodie - Would You Be So Kind? (Türkçe Çeviri)

annotations: Cause I like you, but that’s not enough
it’s nice to have a crush on someone, because it’s a really good feeling, but it’s even better when the person likes you back.

Oh, would you be so kind as to fall in love with me?
 You see, I’m trying
 I know you know that I like you, but that’s not enough
This shows how nervous she’s knowing that the other person knows about her feelings but stayed quiet
’Cause I like you, but that’s not enough
Relationships have to be mutual, and because she really likes him, she wants him to like her back
You see, I’m trying
the singer is trying to compose themselves because the singer has a big crush on the person they are trying to sing it too and they hope they like them back.
Oh, would you be so kind as to fall in love with me?

dodie talks about her relationship with Jon Cozart in her video “pasta is good life is sad”
She says she wanted to go down “relationship avenue” but Jon wanted to go down “casual lane”
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Adu1vglwW80

Let’s swap chests today
 That might help you decide

Many people’s hearts beat faster when their crush is around. By offering to “swap chests,” the singer wants the crush to also experience the feeling. “That might help you decide,” is the singer explaining how it might help the crush decide their feelings after.

I have a question
 It might seem strange
 How are your lungs?
 Are they in pain?
 ’Cause mine are aching
 Think I know why
 I kinda like it, though
 You wanna try?

Usually, people get out of breath when near or talking to their crushes. The singer is explaining how they feel. “You wanna try?” could be the singer, in this case, Dodie, asking if the crush would be able to like them back.

Dodie says she’s always been a fan of writing about bodies, in an interview for her song ‘Human’, Dodie states; “I was such a fan, I still am, of writing about bodies and minds in a gruesome way, like organically. I really like linking feelings to you in a fleshy carcass.” could also explain why she chose to write about lungs specifically
There’s gotta be some butterflies somewhere, wanna share?

Butterflies in the stomach is a common ‘symptom’ of having a crush.

“Wanna share?” shows she wants them to feel these butterflies; she wants her feelings to be reciprocated.
You’ve got to join me on my page

This shows that they are on different pages- she wants a relationship with them, they seemingly don’t feel the same.

“Join me on my page” shows that she wants to change their mind and have her feelings reciprocated.

Oh, do me a favour
 Can your heart rate rise a little?
 Do me a favour
 Can your heart rate rise a little? (ooh)
 Oh do me a favour
 Can your heart rate rise a little? (ooh)
 Do me a favour
This is Dodie asking if their heart rate could rise a little, having your heart rate rise is a commonly associated with being near somebody you fancy. She’s begging this person to like her back.

search_results.title: Air So Sweet
search_results.lyrics:
TranslationsTürkçeAir So Sweet Lyrics[Verse]
I run barefoot, shoes at the door
The air so sweet, I gulp and gasp for more
A night so still, I dance, I soar
Oh, this is what I'm living forYou might also like2Embed

description.plain:
“Air So Sweet” originally came out as a demo on dodie’s second YouTube channel, doddlevloggle, on October 16, 2018. The demo was originally about 52 seconds long, whereas iTunes lists the official release as 1:05 minutes.

https://youtu.be/l2b_EtYRNgI

In the video shared to doddlevloggle, dodie associates this song with how happy she had been feeling in a particular moment. After she had finished a recording session with Jacob Collier, for what we can assume now was them recording their cover of “Here Comes the Sun” by The Beatles, dodie had felt just really happy. She associates “Air So Sweet” most to her running down her street barefoot (“I was wearing shoes, but I liked the idea of not wearing shoes cuz that’s what it felt like; I felt so grounded for once.”) to her friend and fellow musician, Orla Gartland’s house. From what she shared, this was just focused on the moment of running to Orla’s house feeling excited that they were now neighbors and excited to tell Orla about how great and happy she had been feeling.

This bio was written before the official version of “Air So Sweet” was released

songs.full_title: Dodie - Air So Sweet (Türkçe Çeviri) by Genius Türkçe Çeviri
songs.title: Dodie - Air So Sweet (Türkçe Çeviri)

annotations: Oh, this is what I’m living for

In an Our Culture interview, dodie writes:

I love an instrumental kind of intro. I had one ready, and I knew I wanted to use it. Especially this song in particular, it’s very, like – my arms are open, open to receive anything, whatever the world hits at me. It just feels very alive. So it felt right to go at the beginning and be like, “Hit me. Throw whatever you have at me.”
I run barefoot, shoes at the door

The opening lyric of the album creates a sense of spontaneity and childlike hopefulness, contrasting the darker tones of most of Build A Problem.

Dodie elaborated on this optimism, and the decision to place this song at the beginning of the album, in a feature with ourculture:

I think because the album gets pretty dark – it can be quite heavy, and I don’t even think I realized … I didn’t really plan that, but I think that’s what happens when you naturally turn introspectively and really evaluate all of your feelings. So putting this at the beginning kind of gives it hopefully a positive outlook of like, “This is life. It’s full of extreme highs and extreme lows, but I’m ready for it.”
The air so sweet, I gulp and gasp for more

from a comment on the lyric video : like those fuzzy little moments where nothing hugely exciting is actually happening, but you feel a sudden joy and calm and you feel like life is worth living and everything is going to be alright

description.plain:
“Love To Keep Me Warm” is a single released on December 3rd, 2021, by Laufey featuring Dodie. The single marked the pair’s first collaboration together, as well as Laufey’s second official collaboration with another artist, (succeeding “Let You Break My Heart Again” featuring Philharmonia Orchestra).

Lyrically, the love song conveys the romance amidst the chilly, winter weather. Dodie also regarded the track as a Christmas song, likely due to its wintery, holiday-esque nature. Following its release, the track is now accompanied by an official lyric video on Laufey’s YouTube channel.

description.plain:
This is another original song by Dodie Clark uploaded on her ‘doddleoddle’ YouTube channel on the 20th November 2015. During this song, Dodie talks about how it is hard to stay friends with people after a relationship with them.

The official music video for this song was released on the 9th December 2016.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8qGFAkyfjDU

body.plain:
This is another original song by Dodie Clark uploaded on her ‘doddleoddle’ YouTube channel on the 20th November 2015. During this song, Dodie talks about how it is hard to stay friends with people after a relationship with them.

The official music video for this song was released on the 9th December 2016.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8qGFAkyfjDU

songs.full_title: Dodie - Sick of Losing Soulmates (Türkçe Çeviri) by Genius Türkçe Çeviri
songs.title: Dodie - Sick of Losing Soulmates (Türkçe Çeviri)
songs.title_with_featured: Dodie - Sick of Losing Soulmates (Türkçe Çeviri)

translation_songs.title: Dodie - Sick of Losing Soulmates (Türkçe Çeviri)

annotations: Time and hearts will wear us thin

She feels that the relationship won’t last over time. Other people (the “hearts” mentioned) will pull them apart as well, wearing them thin.
She is sure that this won’t last and that it’s merely something that’ll end soon.

’Cause I’m sick of losing soulmates
 So where do we begin?
In these lyrics, Dodie’s talking about how hard it is to start new friendships or relationships when every single one seems to end, so it’s hard to see the point in starting a new one.

’Cause I’m sick of losing soulmates
 So where do we begin?
In these lyrics, Dodie’s talking about how hard it is to start new friendships or relationships when every single one seems to end, so it’s hard to see the point in starting a new one.

’Cause I’m sick of losing soulmates
 So where do we begin?
In these lyrics, Dodie’s talking about how hard it is to start new friendships or relationships when every single one seems to end, so it’s hard to see the point in starting a new one.
Won’t be alone again

Dodie stated that the person she was in a controlling relationship with isolated her from all her friends and made her move away from home. This line is Dodie stating that she will not let this happen again.

What a strange being you are
 God knows where I would be if you hadn’t found me
 Sitting all alone in the dark

Dodie stated in a video on her YouTube channel that she wrote this song about the time where she had recently left a manipulative, abusive relationship. The person she is writing about found her during this time and helped her come to the realisation that this is not what she deserved.

So which path will you take
 ’Cause we both know a break
 Does exactly what it says on the tin

She is recognizing that a relationship won’t always be easy – it will face challenges.  It can be assumed that the “paths” she mentions are the ones we hear about: the high road or the low road, the easy way or the hard way, the path less traveled by, etc.

She also indicates that she has high levels of relationship efficacy, meaning that no matter how hard things get, she believes that they will make it through together.

In this line, she has no interest in taking a break to see if the relationship really exemplifies what they want in a partner.  It is insinuated that taking a break whilst in a relationship actually damages the relationship more than if they had just stayed together and worked through their differences.

The “tin” is symbolic of taking things at face value.  So if a couple says they’re taking a break, they are simultaneously “breaking” their relationship.

We will grow old as friends
 I’ve promised that before
 So what’s one more in our grey-haired circle
 Waiting for the end?

She is asking her potential partner if they can have something more than a friendship.

In psychology, Sternberg’s Triangular Theory of Love states that consummate love is made up by intimacy, commitment, and passion.  Saying that they’ll grow old as friends indicates that the promise of intimacy – or deep knowledge of each other – and commitment, or a long-term relationship.  This line could be asking for the promise of the third point in the triangle – passion.
Yeah, I’m sick of losing soulmates

Dodie considers some of her closest friends soulmates, she’s lost enough of her friends through the years and wants this ‘soulmate’ relationship to last. Dodie also stated that this song is about how hard it is to stay friends with people after a relationship, this line reflects the fact that she does not want this to happen anymore.

What the hell would I be without you?
 (What the hell would I be?)
 Brave face, talk so lightly, hide the truth
 (Hide the truth)

This person is a part of Dodie, she depends heavily on them. She can’t imagine who she’d be if they left.
The line ‘brave face talk so lightly, hide the truth’ is implying she is scared, and broken, but doesn’t want the boy she is talking to to see this, so she puts on a brave face and makes general conversation, not letting him see what’s really inside.

search_results.title: Monster
search_results.lyrics:

description.plain:
“Monster” was debuted during a live show in Belfast. Dodie teased a studio version of the song on her Instagram story in March 2018 and later announced that it will be a part of her upcoming EP “Human”.

While singing the song on tour she told the audience the subject of the song:

Have you ever looked into the eyes of someone who hates you? That’s what this song is about.

Unlike many of Dodie’s previous studio-produced songs, “Monster” is produced with far less acoustic instrumentation.

song.embed_content: Read “Monster” by ​dodie on Genius
song.title: Monster

body.plain:
“Monster” was debuted during a live show in Belfast. Dodie teased a studio version of the song on her Instagram story in March 2018 and later announced that it will be a part of her upcoming EP “Human”.

While singing the song on tour she told the audience the subject of the song:

Have you ever looked into the eyes of someone who hates you? That’s what this song is about.

Unlike many of Dodie’s previous studio-produced songs, “Monster” is produced with far less acoustic instrumentation.

songs.full_title: Dodie - Monster (Türkçe Çeviri) by Genius Türkçe Çeviri
songs.title: Dodie - Monster (Türkçe Çeviri)

annotations:
High and mighty, at the top of your list
 Adoring every move, now my rank is sinking

This expresses how the idealisation of the protagonist through her lover (expressed by stating that she was high and mighty) turned into the opposite – this also further reinforces the reference to black and white thinking in the following line. She turned from someone considered incredibly, perhaps unattainably highly (high and mighty has a somewhat ambiguous connation) to someone seen as a literal monster. So she goes in the other person’s perception from the best of the best to the worst of the worst, nothing in between.

Mhm, through sharpened teeth
 You break the rules and spikes grow from your skin

This represents the protagonist’s transformation into the monster (metaphorically, in the perception of her lover). Her teeth grow sharper and she grows horns, turning into a grotesque monsterous version of herself. This particularly stresses that this is a sharp change to how she was perceived before.
Get out of my room, smile wiped clean
“Get out of my room” is likely Dodie quoting what they said at the end of their last argument.

Oh, I think it might be worth a try
 Oh, am I ready to let this die?
 Mhm, a monster’s here
 Mhm, you plug your ears
 But hey, you might just listen to it sing
 Please let the devil in

As mentioned above, the line “I’m guessing that I’ve grown horns” implies Dodie believes in the mind of the other party addressed in this song, she seems like a devil. Because their relationship is so damaged and unstable her partner doesn’t listen to her when she speaks, and instead she resorts to song in hopes they’ll listen. She tries to mend their relationship just a little, asking her partner to “Please let the devil in,” thus asking them to open up to her; let her in again and listen to what she’s trying to say in her song.

Well, this ends bad then, we knew it would
 So we won’t eat our words, ’cause they don’t taste good

Dodie and the song’s subject are stuck in an awkward, disappointing limbo; the things said during their falling out were so mean that trying to take them back could only result in more hurt and anger, so they give each other the cold shoulder. “Eat your words” also has a negative connotation, possibly implying that Dodie meant what she said.

Oh, how easily passion twists
 You think I’m a crazy bitch
 I craft my words to fit your head
 ’Cause no one listens to the dead

Their relationship has become so damaged the subject of the song can no longer see her past the lens of their own hurt and anger. She doesn’t bother acting in a way that might challenge their perspective, as she know’s they’ve already decided what to believe. She even goes so far as to speak to them in a way that aligns with that perspective — in their mind the old her is dead, so there’s no point in trying to communicate with them the same way they did in the past.
We shout in our heads, “Are you still in there?”

Both she and the one she’s speaking to attempt to find a trace of what the other person used to be still there. It evokes a bitter sort of nostalgia, as they’re both well aware of what they once had and both wish that they could return to it.

Mhm, you plug your ears
 But hey, you might just listen to it sing

As the first line of the chorus says, she’s using song rather than plain words to try and speak to the subject. She knows they won’t listen to speech, and hopes that singing will draw them to truly listen to her

Tell me again about how it hurts
 Being awfully loud for an introvert

PROPOSED SUGGESTION:

im not entirely sure this song is about an ex. To me it sounds like she is talking to herself. The inner demons (or monster) is being really loud and dark thoughts are expressing the way that everything hurts

So maybe I will talk to you
 The only way I know how to

Here, Dodie reveals that “the only way” she can really express her feelings towards this person is through song.

She has expressed this idea before in the last track of Human, “Burned Out”, in which she sings:

Oh, maybe I’ll talk about it (Maybe I’ll talk about it)
I can just talk about it (I can just talk about it)
I’ll never talk about it (I’ll never talk about it)
No, I cannot talk about it

Meaning, Dodie generally finds it easier to talk about things through song than head on to either her audience or in this case, her ex-partner.

description.plain:
In Dodie’s first solo release since Build a Problem, Dodie writes about her insecurities about dating women.

In a Dork interview, Dodie says:

“The whole song can probably be described as; I get the ick with myself whenever I date girls. It might be internalised biphobia, it might be from lack of representation growing up (“no one told me, course I stumbled”) – but regardless, ‘Got Weird’ is about a kiss with a girl on a date following a faux confident arrangement (“I played the man, and you bought it”), and how clearly, following that, I really have got some “shit to figure out”.”

The song was featured in Dodie’s video “how to write a song"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hbFzz6LXF8M which was screened at the Buffer Festival in London. A snippet of the song demo plays at the end of the video.

song.embed_content: Read “Got Weird” by ​dodie on Genius
song.title: Got Weird

body.plain:
In Dodie’s first solo release since Build a Problem, Dodie writes about her insecurities about dating women.

In a Dork interview, Dodie says:

“The whole song can probably be described as; I get the ick with myself whenever I date girls. It might be internalised biphobia, it might be from lack of representation growing up (“no one told me, course I stumbled”) – but regardless, ‘Got Weird’ is about a kiss with a girl on a date following a faux confident arrangement (“I played the man, and you bought it”), and how clearly, following that, I really have got some “shit to figure out”.”

The song was featured in Dodie’s video “how to write a song"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hbFzz6LXF8M which was screened at the Buffer Festival in London. A snippet of the song demo plays at the end of the video.

annotations: So take a deep breath, a big stretch, baby

On the 23rd of January 2023, Dodie posted a “ some bits about got weird! ” short on her Youtube. Regarding this line she says:

“ Honestly when I was writing I got stuck, so I literally looked around me on what to write next. And this phrase lives on my monitor so I remember to take breaks [focus on an handwritten note at the top right of her monitor].
I sang it to the tune just to fill something in and it stuck! To me now it’s the breath before the pep talk ”
It’ll feel like a movie (Maybe)

Dodie wants to have her ideal “movie moment.” However, even at the beginning of the song, the voice of insecurity is present in the whispered “maybe.” The ideal date she sets up in the first part of the verse has the possibility of being incredible, but Dodie’s feelings of self-doubt and being an imposter (“bootleg boss bitch”) lead to the upsetting kiss.
Let’s not make it deeper than it needs to be

In this line, Dodie (or the speaker) reminds themselves to not overthink the situation. After all of the complicated emotions explored in the song, the bridge returns to the chorus' simple explanation for the situation: they simply “got weird” and want to try again rather than continue worrying about the date or their reasons for getting upset.
Is she a date or a captive?
This line shows the way that dodie doesn’t actually feel confident in herself, believing that their date is trapped and doesn’t actually want to be there.
Bootleg boss bitch

Here, Dodie highlights her insecurity and false confidence. Though they are taking charge of the date and getting ready for a movie moment, they feel like a “bootleg boss bitch:” an imitation of the person they feel they should be. Dodie wants to be cool and confident, yet doesn’t believe she is that sort of person.
Give me an inch, I’ll postpone it
dodie’s date gives her a cue to make a move, but she’s too unsure to make it.

(Hm) No one told me (Hm)
 ’Course I stumbled (Hm)
 Where’s the reference? (Hm-mm)
this line could refer to how queer women don’t have a lot of examples to emulate when dating other women, and how they sometimes “stumble” when having their own experiences.

Poured a drink all over my wiring (Shit)
 Short a fuse, all cylinders firing
Possibly an allusion to a dissociative response when overwhelmed?

Table for two that’s all sorted
 I played the man and you bought it
 We’ll talk over glass like I own it

I think the best way to describe it is satirical lyrical manspreading. dodie often uses her songs to explore themes around her bisexuality. An irritatingly common question for female couples is ‘who wears the trousers in the relationship?’ which dodie plays on here, coveting the gin glasses at the bar and establishing a possessive masculine presence
Any chips or nuts for the hostage?

dodie’s self-proclaimed weirdest lyric (on her Instagram story) , I love the dichotomy of pleasantries against a foreboding backdrop. The lyric also augments the semantic field of a date night, most likely at a bar.

description.plain:
“Ready Now” was written for the episode “The Invisible Child” from the 2019 animated TV series Moomin Valley, which takes its inspiration from Tove and Lars Jansson’s book and comic series The Moomins.

In a YouTube video dodie made for the song she explained:

I wrote this about a best friend who helped me find myself again after feeling lost in an unhealthy relationship. It’s called “Ready Now” because I am.

song.embed_content: Read “Ready Now” by ​dodie on Genius
song.title: Ready Now

body.plain:
“Ready Now” was written for the episode “The Invisible Child” from the 2019 animated TV series Moomin Valley, which takes its inspiration from Tove and Lars Jansson’s book and comic series The Moomins.

In a YouTube video dodie made for the song she explained:

I wrote this about a best friend who helped me find myself again after feeling lost in an unhealthy relationship. It’s called “Ready Now” because I am.

annotations:
Something new, something strange
 Ten feet taller, I had changed

This song is about dodie getting help finding herself after coming out of a toxic relationship. She is saying that when she got out of that relationship, she had changed as a person and it was better for her.
And I told the world

This line changes across the two pre-choruses, the first saying that the world told her that she had a plan the second that she told the world that she has a plan. This shows the change in her control and her feelings. at the beginning of the song, she was being led by a friend down a healthy path, and by the end, she could lead herself and stand on her own two feet.

You said ”I will listen, tell me it all
 You don’t like the ending?
 Then we’ll find one that’s yours”
This shows the control over a point in their lives, where instead of letting someone else control or dictate the narrative they are the main character in their story.

You saw through me all this time
 I’d forgotten people are kind
 I was hurting and you knew
 So you showed me what to do
 You said ”I will listen, tell it all
 When you’re finished we’ll talk more”

The subject of the song may have “seen through” dodie because they themselves had been in a similar situation. This draws a parallel to dodie’s 2015 song “Sick of Losing Soulmates”; in which she speaks of a conversation she had with her friend after leaving an abusive relationship:

I’d recently come out of a very bad relationship with a abusive person […] and this other person found me and sat me down […] and we had a massive chat. […] I was pretty broken and I was leaning on someone who told me all about their experiences. [They were] proof [that] you can still live and be functioning.

description.plain:
“Hot Mess” was the first song created by Dodie for a project to create a song every month for the year 2022. A demo of “Hot Mess” was released on February 1, and the studio version was released on September 2nd, 2022 along with an announcement for an EP of the same name.

The lyric video for Hot Mess:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=meeWulQosl4

The original demo:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rlSVL774OGk

song.embed_content: Read “Hot Mess” by ​dodie on Genius
song.title: Hot Mess

body.plain:
“Hot Mess” was the first song created by Dodie for a project to create a song every month for the year 2022. A demo of “Hot Mess” was released on February 1, and the studio version was released on September 2nd, 2022 along with an announcement for an EP of the same name.

The lyric video for Hot Mess:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=meeWulQosl4

The original demo:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rlSVL774OGk

annotations: Dry heave, I am not okay

Dry heaving is a symptom some people experience when they are anxious or stressed, a symptom which dodie herself has admitted to experiencing:

I really did dry heave after receiving a text
Now what, my darling? Two years have passed

In her vlog, “june (the month behind my new song)” Dodie states, “I’m still hung up on the same boy for three fucking years.”
For her September vlog, “yeah ow (sept.), she states that she is trying to finally let go. "This one was nice,” she says.

Dodie has spent a long time in an on again off again relationship, waiting for things to change with time.

Let me let go
 Let me let go
 Let me let go
Despite Dodie’s attempts to leave the relationship, she’s having trouble bringing herself to do it. She’s possibly trying to urge her partner to do something to make her want to break up with them.
Don’t know, I am still unclear

The new year is supposed to be a time of new beginnings. However, dodie highlights an all-too-common experience: problems from the past year will, inevitably, continue into the new one. Dodie is still “unclear” on what she is doing, and eventually goes on to sing the rest of the chorus, emphasizing the repetitiveness of life and of trying to move on from old issues.
Exit to the end in sight, dear

Dodie sees the end of the relationship or situation, and tells herself to leave it as soon as she can.
Again, this could be interpreted as Dodie speaking to herself- gently reminding herself to leave the situation- or to someone else- telling them to end the relationships.
Make it ugly, put on a show

“Making it ugly” is part of Dodie’s way of trying to hate their partner so that they can “let go”. She makes the breakup worse than it actually is, and tries to “put on a show” of how much she hates the other person, in order to ultimately “let go” and stop loving them.
I’m a hot mess

In her song, “Got Weird” Dodie sings, “Guess hot god-damn mess is your type then.” Both of these songs are planned to go on her upcoming and highly anticipated EP, Hot Mess. Some people may be wondering if being a hot mess is the theme of this EP!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZhskLrsvHIg
Hack it that I hate you so that I can let go

dodie uses this very relatable lyric to convey how she’s terrified of facing her own feelings. By “Hacking it” or tricking herself into thinking that she hates her ex, she thinks that she’ll be able to let go of her feelings and this person.
Count down, happy new year
In the background of this lyric in the song, you can hear a new year’s countdown and cheering. This is an actual recording of dodie and her friends during the 2020 new year.
God, twenty-seven, still cryin’ in cars

This is likely referencing the visuals from Build a Problem, which feature her in cars, crying during many of the songs. Dodie is still processing all of the emotions from that period of her life and having new problems to sort out. Though she has grown, and may have expected to be more content, she still experiences the same (negative) emotions.

Additionally, cars are a space for movement and transition. By saying that she is “crying in cars,” she shows how she is not yet fully settled at 27, instead feeling like she is still constantly changing.
